DOC.HEAD: Lawyer: Domino's Pizza Driver Calls Boss After Wreck to Make Delivery
DOC.TEXT: A Domino's Pizza driver who hit another motorist while making a delivery called his boss and had him come and get the pie to meet the company's 30-minute guarantee, a lawyer claims in a negligence lawsuit. Ramon Rigal says he suffered back injuries and a concussion when his Chevrolet Blazer, which was stopped for a turn, was struck from behind by a Volkswagen driven by a 19-year-old Domino's delivery man. Police say the April accident caused $9,000 damage to the two cars. ``After the crash, the pizza man calls his boss, who shows up to take the handoff of the pizza and finish the delivery,'' attorney Paul Nelson said in an interview Friday. The Rigals ``are out there waiting for the paramedics to come, and all they do is hand off this pizza,'' Nelson said, blaming the accident on Domino's policy of guaranteeing pizza delivery in 30 minutes or giving customers $3 off their bill. Rigal, a commercial artist, is unable to work and on the verge of bankruptcy, Nelson said. The amount of damages Rigal is seeking wasn't specified. Domino's refused to comment on the lawsuit, which was filed in Hillsborough Circuit Court last month. The lawsuit is the latest in a series of actions blaming a traffic accident on a Domino's delivery driver rushing to meet the half-hour deadline. Seven such lawsuits have been filed against the pizza maker in the last two years in Hillsborough County, and four have been filed in the last few years in Pinellas Circuit Court in neighboring St. Petersburg. Ron Hingst, director of public relations for Domino's, emphasizes that drivers aren't penalized if they take longer than 30 minutes. ``The $3 doesn't come out of the driver's pocket; it's built into the budget of each store.''
